input: scene: a prehistoric setting. description: A man is standing atop a pile of rocks. A woman is on the ground looking up at him. uncanny: The rocks are stacked in an odd shape. entities: Caveman, Paleolithic, Stone_Age. caption: So that's where all the furniture went.
target: The cave wife is upset at the cave woman for building the pile of rocks because the rocks also acted as the furniture in their house. It's not clear why the man did this to their house; and also, because cave people don't usually have furniture, imagining their fancy, elaborate rock furniture house is funny.
caption_choices: So that's where all the furniture went.
generated_idefics: The image shows a man standing on top of a large pile of rocks, and a small child is standing next to him. The man appears to be explaining something to the child. The joke lies in the fact that the man is referring to the pile of rocks as "furniture," which is an unconventional and humorous way to describe the pile.

input: scene: a field description: A bull is talking to a cow in a field. There are swords sticking out of a bull. uncanny: The bull is not dead despite being stabbed numerous times. entities: Cattle, Bull, Dagger. caption: I didn't mean your day wasn't hard, too.
target: Couples sometimes compare/bicker about how hard their work days were --- here, the cow and bull are a couple. The cow is pouting because the bull isn't sympathetic about the her day, but the bull's day really does seem harder because, as evidenced by the swords stabbed in its back, it was in a bullfight. It's funny not only because the animals are having a stereotypical couple conversation, but also because the cow doesn't really seem to care about the swords, which mirrors emotional disconnectedness of human couples fighting.
caption_choices: I didn't mean your day wasn't hard, too.
generated_idefics: The joke in this image is the humorous depiction of two cows standing in a field, with one of them wearing a crown on its head. This is likely a reference to the concept of royalty or kingship, and the fact that the crowned cow is looking at the other cow, which is not wearing a crown, adds to the amusement.

input: scene: outside a home description: A man and woman are staring out their window. It is raining safe,s which are crushing things. uncanny: It doesn't rain safes in the real world. entities: Safe, Rain. caption: And tomorrow there's a twenty-per-cent chance of anvils.
target: In a world where safes rain down from the sky, it might make sense that anvils would too. This is a reference to a falling anvil, a trope from TVs/movies, where anvils fall and hit people on the head. In this odd world, the weather reports don't talk about chances of sun/rain, they report things like a 20% chance of anvils tomorrow.
caption_choices: And tomorrow there's a twenty-per-cent chance of anvils.
generated_idefics: This joke is a play on words, where the speaker is using the word "announcements" to refer to unexpected events or objects falling from the sky. The word "announcements" can also be read as "annuals," which are publications that provide information or stories about a particular year or event. The speaker is essentially saying that there will be a lot of unexpected events or objects falling from the sky, similar to how annuals provide information about a specific year.

input: scene: a business office description: A man is sitting at a table with his hand on a phone. There is a vulture perched in front of him. uncanny: A vulture is an unusual bird to have indoors. entities: Businessperson, Vulture, Speakerphone. caption: Janice, hold all my calls. Indefinitely.
target: A vulture often circles over a nearly dead animal in the wild to scavenge its corpse for food. The joke here is that, the vulture has identified the man as someone about to die, and, surprisingly, he also agrees: he nonchalantly tells his secretary to hold his calls/work forever, because he's about to die. He doesn't seem to care that he's about to die, and instead focuses on his benign work obligations, which is funny.
caption_choices: Janice, hold all my calls. Indefinitely.
generated_idefics: The joke in this image is that the man is being interviewed by a bird, which is an unusual and unexpected scenario. The man is dressed in a suit and tie, and he is sitting at a desk with a typewriter, which suggests that he might be a professional or a businessman. The bird is pecking at a piece of paper, which implies that it is taking notes or evaluating the man's performance during the interview.

input: scene: sea description: People are in a boat paddling. A huge wave with a scary face and arms tries to get them. The Statue of Liberty is in the background. uncanny: The waves have a face and arms. entities: Rowing, Immigration, Wind_wave. caption: Row v. Wave.
target: A play on "Row v. Wade", a supreme court case which established a woman's right to access abortions. Here, the wave looks like Donald Trump, a conservative politician who is attempting to overturn row v. wade so women can't legally access abortions. And, the public in the boat who support a woman's right to choose are literally rowing a boat against the wave. So both "Row" and "Wave" have double meanings.
generated_idefics: The image is a play on the legal term "row v. wade," which refers to the case Row v. Wade, a landmark U.S. Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationwide. In this image, the "row v. wade" sign on the boat may indicate that the passengers are arguing about whether to row against the waves or to give up and return to shore.
